ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned so much about how research is carried out. It was nice to have someone teach things to us that professors usually assume you just know, or that a single methods lecture should cover. I feel like I understand how to read studies much better know and can more accurately use what I read in papers and projects, since I know what claims are being made.
A thorough introduction to designing and completing experimental studies.
The mechanics of constructing Qualtrics surveys; running ANOVA interaction effects.
How to write a great academic APA paper for psychology; how to provide concise and effective feedback to my peers; how to think critically about my writing, work, and other literature.

I learnt how to design a psychology research project, which is a crucial skill for any budding psychologist. I learnt how to organize and synthesize results, and communicate them concisely in a research paper. I also learnt about the strengths and weaknesses of different ways of answering a psychology research question, and how to weigh each one when designing our own psychology research project.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I can't really think of a way to improve this class. It's perfectly organized and really fair/
This class is really well structured, which helps greatly with the learning process. My only suggestion would be perhaps try to cut down a bit on the work in the first half of the semester.

I really appreciated the methodical and deliberate nature of the class divided into modules with small assignments and feedback. It felt like learning for the sake of learning as opposed to for a grade.

However, I also was frustrated that I did a lot of extra labor just as a result of being a QTPOC in conversations about race and gender demographic questions that really should've been the Professor and TF's job
I can't think of anything that would improve the course
This course was well-run as far as helping students learn. It was definitely a lot of work because of how many small assignments there are, but that also forces you to stay caught up with the class.

The course was very structured, and allowed us to build upon knowledge learnt in each week in a very easy to follow format. Professor Hirsch was very patient, engaged and gave very clear feedback on all writing assignments on ways it can be improved. This course teaches you how to summarize results clearly and how to communicate research very concisely and clearly. One weakness of the course is that deadlines for larger assignments were often not spaced out enough to allow time to submit drafts.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The only thing I didn't like was having to do a group project virtually, but honestly it was probably character building for me overall. I do think Prof Hirsch had a really good way of leading classes over zoom.
Class on zoom was great!
The small group lab meetings worked great!

The break out rooms during class time were very effective, and allowed us to learn from other students and discuss possible research designs for the example scenario presented. It was difficult to learn how to use SPSS in a virtual format, since we were not able to seek help as efficiently.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes!!
I definitely would recommend it. I wish we could take this class earlier because it would have helped me to take as a sophomore. It really helped me understand coursework in other classes.
Yes, specifically with Professor Hirsch.
It is required for the PSYC major but Professor Hirsch made it a delight!

I would highly recommend this course to any student that aims to be a psychological researcher, since this course teaches you how to write a research paper, and how to design ways to answer any psychological research question. Overall, this course equips any student with the skills to answer research questions, and how to evaluate results.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We also used virtual break out rooms to talk to other students about their research questions, and receive feedback from each other on our projects.
